newsitem.title: USA: Mercury says has extension of $50 million credit line.
newsitem.headline: Mercury says has extension of $50 million credit line.

text.p: Troubled auto lender Mercury Finance Co. said Thursday its creditors granted waivers allowing a 90-day extension of its $50 million line of credit with Bank of America to June 10.

The waivers permit Mercury, which faces a federal investigation, to continue to pledge assets as collateral on the $50 million credit facility. The previous waiver period had been only for 30 days, Chicago-based Mercury said.

The company also has been hit by several shareholder lawsuits, had to restate its financial results to show lower earnings due to accounting irregularities, and lost more than $2 billion in market capitalisation after a plunge in its stock price.
The stock fell in January after the news of the earnings restatement from $14 to less than $2 per share. It rose 50 cents to $3 in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
"This 90-day extension is a tangible demonstration of confidence in Mercury," said Chief Executive William Brandt.
"The expanded waiver period gives the company breathing room to focus on operations and on the exploration of long-term financing alternatives," he said.

Under the terms of the waivers, during the 90-day period, the company will resume interest payments on nearly all of its roughly $1 billion in debt and will pay any interest that is now past due, Mercury said.
Mercury received the $50 million in short-term financing from Bank of America a month ago. The financing is being used to meet daily operating expenses and interest payments.
